page.title: 14Cilcain:Employment/Commuting
page.content: In the 19th century most local people worked in the immediate vicinity, many being employed on farms, some in lead- mining and others providing goods and services for the rural population. Now there are some jobs at nearby limestone quarries, but mechanization on farms means that far fewer people gain a living from agriculture. The shops, public-houses, school and a few small businesses, such as a riding- stables and a mobile blacksmith, provide a few jobs locally, but most residents have to find work outside the villages. Many are employed in the Mold area, but some commute longer distances to work in Chester, Deeside, or Merseyside. Recent improvements to the main roads of the area mean such a journey does not take long by car, and these people value life in this rural environment above the costs of travel.
